title: How to Make a Wizard Hat

steps.headline: Cut out a semi-circle from construction paper.
Roll the paper into a cone.
steps.description: As you shape the paper, keep the bottom edge level with your working surface so that it can rest perfectly flat on that surface. Hold the overlapping edge together using double-sided tape or glue. If you use glue, you might need to use a stapler to hold the bottom edge of the cone in place as the glue dries.

steps.headline: Cut fringes into the base of the hat.
steps.description: Each fringe should be about 1/3 inch (1 cm) long and 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart. Fold these fringes so that they stick out from the bottom of the cone. You will use these fringes later to attach the brim of your hat to the main conical portion.

steps.headline: Draw a brim for your hat.
Adhere the brim to your hat.
Cut out decorations.
Glue the decorations to the hat.
steps.description: Apply glue to the back of each decoration and arrange them at random over the cone body of the hat.

steps.headline: Wear when dry.
steps.description: Once all the glue is dry, the wizard hat is ready to wear and show off.

steps.headline: Cut a semi-circle from fusible interfacing.
steps.description: Determine how tall you want your wizard hat to be. Situate a fabric pencil inside a compass, then set the compass so that it matches your desired height measurement. Draw a half-circle onto the interfacing and cut it out with sharp scissors. Usually, a 9 to 10 inch (23 to 25 cm) hat is tall enough for toddlers and young children, while older kids and young adults might need a hat 11 to 12 inches (28 to 30 cm) tall, if not a bit taller. When drawing the circle, place the fixed leg of your compass in the middle of the bottom edge of your interfacing. Draw a half-circle around this point, extending out and around the bottom edge from above. Note that the flat edge of your half-circle will be twice as long as the shape's height. If you have your heart set on a specific height, add another 1 inch (2.5 cm) to that measurement for a seam allowance.

steps.headline: Roll the material into a cone.
steps.description: Roll the interfacing so that it comes to a peak at the top part of the curved edge. Keep the bottom flat against your working surface as you work. Once the opening at the bottom of your hat appears small enough to rest on the intended wearer's head, pin it in place and test the cone. If it rests securely on the wearer's head, move on. If it does not sit on the head well, though, widen or narrow the opening as needed to improve the fit.

steps.headline: Trim the excess.
steps.description: Once you achieve a perfect fit with your cone, carefully cut away some of the excess interfacing from the inside of the body. Remove just enough to get rid of any excess bulk. Leave at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of overlapping material inside the hat.

steps.headline: Transfer the shape onto your fabric.
Iron the two pieces together.
steps.description: Carefully press the interfacing on the fabric using an iron set to low heat. Press as needed until the two pieces of material are securely attached to each other. If you are using a synthetic material, you will need to use a low heat setting and work as carefully as possible to prevent the fabric from melting. Read the exact instructions for your interfacing before attempting to iron it on. While the procedure is generally the same for each type of interfacing, some may require slightly different steps.

steps.headline: Sew the side.
Cut a brim from interfacing and fabric.
Iron the brim pieces together.
steps.description: Use a hot iron to fuse the interfacing onto the fabric. Make sure that the pieces are securely joined before continuing past this step. Use the same heat setting, time, and pressure to fuse the brim material as you used when fusing the material for the body of the hat.

steps.headline: Hem the brim, if necessary.
steps.description: If you are using a material that frays, fold the inside edge and outside edge under by about 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) each. Pin in place, then carefully back stitch by hand to secure the hem. Skip this step if you are using felt or another fray-resistant material.

steps.headline: Cut slits into the bottom of the hat.
steps.description: Return to the conical body of the hat. Use sharp scissors to cut 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) slits around the entire body, each one spaced roughly 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart.

steps.headline: Attach the brim to the bottom of the hat.
Decorate as desired.
Show off your wizard hat.
steps.description: After you finish decorating the hat, put it on and wear it proudly.

tyn: Decorations like stickers, glitter, or paint
Making a Wizard Hat Out of Felt
Sewing machine or a sewing needle and thread
text:
Method One: Paper Wizard Hat Cut out a semi-circle from construction paper. Set a compass to a length between 9 to 12 inches (23 to 30 cm), depending on the size of the wearer's head. Place the point of the compass in the middle of the bottom edge and draw a half-circle using the attached pencil. Cut this shape out with scissors after drawing it. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} The exact size of your hat should vary based on the size of the intended wearer. For a toddler or young child, make the radius 9 or 10 inches (23 or 25 cm) long. For a slightly older child, use a radius of 11 or 12 (28 or 30 cm) inches. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Roll the paper into a cone. As you shape the paper, keep the bottom edge level with your working surface so that it can rest perfectly flat on that surface. Hold the overlapping edge together using double-sided tape or glue. If you use glue, you might need to use a stapler to hold the bottom edge of the cone in place as the glue dries. Cut fringes into the base of the hat. Each fringe should be about 1/3 inch (1 cm) long and 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart. Fold these fringes so that they stick out from the bottom of the cone. You will use these fringes later to attach the brim of your hat to the main conical portion. Draw a brim for your hat. On a new sheet of construction paper, draw a line that is equal in length to the diameter of hat's opening. Draw a circle around this line, then draw a bigger circle around that. Cut out the larger circle and the smaller circle, and use the large ring left behind as your brim. Measure the inside diameter of your cone several times and at several places. Use the smallest measurement you get when deciding on the diameter of your brim. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} When drawing the inner circle of your brim, place the pointed end of the compass on the midpoint of your diameter line and set the compass to half the diameter's length. Draw around the line, making sure that your perimeter touches both ends of the line. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} After drawing the inner circle, set the compass so that your new radius is 3 inches (7.6 cm) larger than the radius of your inner circle. Use the same center point and draw a larger circle evenly around the smaller inner circle. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} You can discard the inner circle after cutting them both out. You only need the outer ring for your brim. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet4.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Adhere the brim to your hat. Slide the brim over the top of the hat and onto the fringes at the base. Glue or tape the brim to these fringes from the underside. The brim should fit snugly on the fringes of the cone. If you cannot slide it all the way down to these fringes, however, carefully cut away extra paper from the inside ring of the brim and try again. Repeat as needed until the brim lies flat on top of the flaps. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} The easiest way to attach the brim to the fringes of the hat is to apply glue or double-sided tape to the bottom inner ring of the brim before sliding it onto the flaps. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut out decorations. If you have stickers or other pre-made decorations you plan on using, skip this step. Otherwise, sketch several stars and crescent moons onto a sheet of shiny aluminum foil and cut them out using a sharp pair of scissors. If you do not want to use aluminum foil, you could use plain construction paper, instead. For an added touch, decorate plain paper embellishments with glitter or sparkly paint. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} You can also paint decorations directly onto the hat instead of cutting out shapes from other material. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Glue the decorations to the hat. Apply glue to the back of each decoration and arrange them at random over the cone body of the hat. Wear when dry. Once all the glue is dry, the wizard hat is ready to wear and show off. Method Two: Cloth Wizard Hat Cut a semi-circle from fusible interfacing. Determine how tall you want your wizard hat to be. Situate a fabric pencil inside a compass, then set the compass so that it matches your desired height measurement. Draw a half-circle onto the interfacing and cut it out with sharp scissors. Usually, a 9 to 10 inch (23 to 25 cm) hat is tall enough for toddlers and young children, while older kids and young adults might need a hat 11 to 12 inches (28 to 30 cm) tall, if not a bit taller. When drawing the circle, place the fixed leg of your compass in the middle of the bottom edge of your interfacing. Draw a half-circle around this point, extending out and around the bottom edge from above. Note that the flat edge of your half-circle will be twice as long as the shape's height. If you have your heart set on a specific height, add another 1 inch (2.5 cm) to that measurement for a seam allowance. Roll the material into a cone. Roll the interfacing so that it comes to a peak at the top part of the curved edge. Keep the bottom flat against your working surface as you work. Once the opening at the bottom of your hat appears small enough to rest on the intended wearer's head, pin it in place and test the cone. If it rests securely on the wearer's head, move on. If it does not sit on the head well, though, widen or narrow the opening as needed to improve the fit. Trim the excess. Once you achieve a perfect fit with your cone, carefully cut away some of the excess interfacing from the inside of the body. Remove just enough to get rid of any excess bulk. Leave at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of overlapping material inside the hat. Transfer the shape onto your fabric. Unpin the trimmed interfacing and lay it flat onto your intended fabric. Pin in place, then cut out a piece of fabric that matches the outline of your interfacing exactly. Make sure that the adhesive side of the interfacing faces your fabric as you cut the fabric out. The adhesive side is usually the glossy side. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Choose a fabric type you feel comfortable working with. Synthetic satin is cost-effective and has a traditional look, but the edges can fray easily and some hemming will be required. Felt has a less traditional look, but it is both inexpensive and easy to work with since it does not fray. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Iron the two pieces together. Carefully press the interfacing on the fabric using an iron set to low heat. Press as needed until the two pieces of material are securely attached to each other. If you are using a synthetic material, you will need to use a low heat setting and work as carefully as possible to prevent the fabric from melting. Read the exact instructions for your interfacing before attempting to iron it on. While the procedure is generally the same for each type of interfacing, some may require slightly different steps. Sew the side. Roll the material back into a cone and pin in it in place. Hand stitch the side of the cone using a neat back stitch. Alternatively, you could glue the edge in place with hot glue if you want a no-sew option. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} If you are working with a fray-resistant fabric like felt, you do not need to worry about hems. If you are using a material that frays, however, you should hem the side edges with a 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) seam allowance before rolling the hat into a cone. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut a brim from interfacing and fabric. Measure the opening at the base of your cone. Use a compass fitted with a fabric pencil to draw a circle of the same diameter onto a piece of interfacing. Draw a second circle around the first that is 2 to 3 inches (5 to 7.6 cm) wider. Cut out both circles so that you are left with a large ring of interfacing. Pin the interfacing to your fabric with the fusible side facing down. Cut the fabric out, as well. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Note that you should add an extra 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) to both the inside and outside of the ring if you are using material that frays, like satin. This extra fabric will be used as a seam allowance for a hem. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Iron the brim pieces together. Use a hot iron to fuse the interfacing onto the fabric. Make sure that the pieces are securely joined before continuing past this step. Use the same heat setting, time, and pressure to fuse the brim material as you used when fusing the material for the body of the hat. Hem the brim, if necessary. If you are using a material that frays, fold the inside edge and outside edge under by about 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) each. Pin in place, then carefully back stitch by hand to secure the hem. Skip this step if you are using felt or another fray-resistant material. Cut slits into the bottom of the hat. Return to the conical body of the hat. Use sharp scissors to cut 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) slits around the entire body, each one spaced roughly 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart. Attach the brim to the bottom of the hat. Slide the brim onto the hat so that the inner ring rests flat on top of the flaps at the cone's base. Hot glue or stitch each of these flaps onto the ring from the underside of the hat. Unless the bottom edge of the cone has frayed significantly, you should not need to hem it before attaching the brim. The glue or thread used to secure the brim onto the hat should prevent the lower edge from fraying, thereby negating the need for a separate hem. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} As you sew the brim onto the hat, keep your stitches as flat as possible. Do not pull the thread too tightly or the fabric will bunch up. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Decorate as desired. The basic structure of your hat is done at this point, so all you need to do is decorate it to your liking. Some ideas include: Cut out stars and crescent moons from yellow felt and hot glue the shapes onto your hat. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cover the seam with a strip of decorative ribbon, or wrap a long piece of ribbon around the hat in a spiral. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Look for small patches, beads, or craft embellishments to glue, sew, or iron onto the hat in a random pattern. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Show off your wizard hat. After you finish decorating the hat, put it on and wear it proudly.
sentences: Method One: Paper Wizard Hat Cut out a semi-circle from construction paper.
Set a compass to a length between 9 to 12 inches (23 to 30 cm), depending on the size of the wearer's head.
Place the point of the compass in the middle of the bottom edge and draw a half-circle using the attached pencil.
Cut this shape out with scissors after drawing it.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/12\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/12\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} The exact size of your hat should vary based on the size of the intended wearer.
For a toddler or young child, make the radius 9 or 10 inches (23 or 25 cm) long.
For a slightly older child, use a radius of 11 or 12 (28 or 30 cm) inches.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/04\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/04\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Roll the paper into a cone.
As you shape the paper, keep the bottom edge level with your working surface so that it can rest perfectly flat on that surface.
Hold the overlapping edge together using double-sided tape or glue.
If you use glue, you might need to use a stapler to hold the bottom edge of the cone in place as the glue dries.
Cut fringes into the base of the hat.
Each fringe should be about 1/3 inch (1 cm) long and 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart.
Fold these fringes so that they stick out from the bottom of the cone.
You will use these fringes later to attach the brim of your hat to the main conical portion.
Draw a brim for your hat.
On a new sheet of construction paper, draw a line that is equal in length to the diameter of hat's opening.
Draw a circle around this line, then draw a bigger circle around that.
Cut out the larger circle and the smaller circle, and use the large ring left behind as your brim.
Measure the inside diameter of your cone several times and at several places.
Use the smallest measurement you get when deciding on the diameter of your brim.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/31\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/31\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} When drawing the inner circle of your brim, place the pointed end of the compass on the midpoint of your diameter line and set the compass to half the diameter's length.
Draw around the line, making sure that your perimeter touches both ends of the line.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} After drawing the inner circle, set the compass so that your new radius is 3 inches (7.6 cm) larger than the radius of your inner circle.
Use the same center point and draw a larger circle evenly around the smaller inner circle.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/bd\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/bd\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet3.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} You can discard the inner circle after cutting them both out.
You only need the outer ring for your brim.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/85\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet4.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/85\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet4.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-4Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Adhere the brim to your hat.
Slide the brim over the top of the hat and onto the fringes at the base.
Glue or tape the brim to these fringes from the underside.
The brim should fit snugly on the fringes of the cone.
If you cannot slide it all the way down to these fringes, however, carefully cut away extra paper from the inside ring of the brim and try again.
Repeat as needed until the brim lies flat on top of the flaps.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b3\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b3\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} The easiest way to attach the brim to the fringes of the hat is to apply glue or double-sided tape to the bottom inner ring of the brim before sliding it onto the flaps.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/83\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/83\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Cut out decorations.
If you have stickers or other pre-made decorations you plan on using, skip this step.
Otherwise, sketch several stars and crescent moons onto a sheet of shiny aluminum foil and cut them out using a sharp pair of scissors.
If you do not want to use aluminum foil, you could use plain construction paper, instead.
For an added touch, decorate plain paper embellishments with glitter or sparkly paint.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/00\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/00\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} You can also paint decorations directly onto the hat instead of cutting out shapes from other material.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/85\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/85\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Glue the decorations to the hat.
Apply glue to the back of each decoration and arrange them at random over the cone body of the hat.
Wear when dry.
Once all the glue is dry, the wizard hat is ready to wear and show off.
Method Two: Cloth Wizard Hat Cut a semi-circle from fusible interfacing.
Determine how tall you want your wizard hat to be.
Situate a fabric pencil inside a compass, then set the compass so that it matches your desired height measurement.
Draw a half-circle onto the interfacing and cut it out with sharp scissors.
Usually, a 9 to 10 inch (23 to 25 cm) hat is tall enough for toddlers and young children, while older kids and young adults might need a hat 11 to 12 inches (28 to 30 cm) tall, if not a bit taller.
When drawing the circle, place the fixed leg of your compass in the middle of the bottom edge of your interfacing.
Draw a half-circle around this point, extending out and around the bottom edge from above.
Note that the flat edge of your half-circle will be twice as long as the shape's height.
If you have your heart set on a specific height, add another 1 inch (2.5 cm) to that measurement for a seam allowance.
Roll the material into a cone.
Roll the interfacing so that it comes to a peak at the top part of the curved edge.
Keep the bottom flat against your working surface as you work.
Once the opening at the bottom of your hat appears small enough to rest on the intended wearer's head, pin it in place and test the cone.
If it rests securely on the wearer's head, move on.
If it does not sit on the head well, though, widen or narrow the opening as needed to improve the fit.
Trim the excess.
Once you achieve a perfect fit with your cone, carefully cut away some of the excess interfacing from the inside of the body.
Remove just enough to get rid of any excess bulk.
Leave at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of overlapping material inside the hat.
Transfer the shape onto your fabric.
Unpin the trimmed interfacing and lay it flat onto your intended fabric.
Pin in place, then cut out a piece of fabric that matches the outline of your interfacing exactly.
Make sure that the adhesive side of the interfacing faces your fabric as you cut the fabric out.
The adhesive side is usually the glossy side.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/16\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/16\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Choose a fabric type you feel comfortable working with.
Synthetic satin is cost-effective and has a traditional look, but the edges can fray easily and some hemming will be required.
Felt has a less traditional look, but it is both inexpensive and easy to work with since it does not fray.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/ba\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/ba\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Iron the two pieces together.
Carefully press the interfacing on the fabric using an iron set to low heat.
Press as needed until the two pieces of material are securely attached to each other.
If you are using a synthetic material, you will need to use a low heat setting and work as carefully as possible to prevent the fabric from melting.
Read the exact instructions for your interfacing before attempting to iron it on.
While the procedure is generally the same for each type of interfacing, some may require slightly different steps.
Sew the side.
Roll the material back into a cone and pin in it in place.
Hand stitch the side of the cone using a neat back stitch.
Alternatively, you could glue the edge in place with hot glue if you want a no-sew option.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0f\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0f\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} If you are working with a fray-resistant fabric like felt, you do not need to worry about hems.
If you are using a material that frays, however, you should hem the side edges with a 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) seam allowance before rolling the hat into a cone.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1e\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1e\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-14Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Cut a brim from interfacing and fabric.
Measure the opening at the base of your cone.
Use a compass fitted with a fabric pencil to draw a circle of the same diameter onto a piece of interfacing.
Draw a second circle around the first that is 2 to 3 inches (5 to 7.6 cm) wider.
Cut out both circles so that you are left with a large ring of interfacing.
Pin the interfacing to your fabric with the fusible side facing down.
Cut the fabric out, as well.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/5c\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/5c\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Note that you should add an extra 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) to both the inside and outside of the ring if you are using material that frays, like satin.
This extra fabric will be used as a seam allowance for a hem.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2d\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2d\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-15Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Iron the brim pieces together.
Use a hot iron to fuse the interfacing onto the fabric.
Make sure that the pieces are securely joined before continuing past this step.
Use the same heat setting, time, and pressure to fuse the brim material as you used when fusing the material for the body of the hat.
Hem the brim, if necessary.
If you are using a material that frays, fold the inside edge and outside edge under by about 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) each.
Pin in place, then carefully back stitch by hand to secure the hem.
Skip this step if you are using felt or another fray-resistant material.
Cut slits into the bottom of the hat.
Return to the conical body of the hat.
Use sharp scissors to cut 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) slits around the entire body, each one spaced roughly 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart.
Attach the brim to the bottom of the hat.
Slide the brim onto the hat so that the inner ring rests flat on top of the flaps at the cone's base.
Hot glue or stitch each of these flaps onto the ring from the underside of the hat.
Unless the bottom edge of the cone has frayed significantly, you should not need to hem it before attaching the brim.
The glue or thread used to secure the brim onto the hat should prevent the lower edge from fraying, thereby negating the need for a separate hem.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/33\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/33\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} As you sew the brim onto the hat, keep your stitches as flat as possible.
Do not pull the thread too tightly or the fabric will bunch up.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/46\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/46\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-19Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Decorate as desired.
The basic structure of your hat is done at this point, so all you need to do is decorate it to your liking.

Some ideas include:
Cut out stars and crescent moons from yellow felt and hot glue the shapes onto your hat.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7f\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7f\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Cover the seam with a strip of decorative ribbon, or wrap a long piece of ribbon around the hat in a spiral.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/24\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/24\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Look for small patches, beads, or craft embellishments to glue, sew, or iron onto the hat in a random pattern.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c9\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c9\/Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet3.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Wizard-Hat-Step-20Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Show off your wizard hat.
After you finish decorating the hat, put it on and wear it proudly.
